name: Introductory Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts and theories of psychology. Topics include neuroscience, sensation and perception, learning, memory, cognition, motivation, emotion, personality, social psychology, and abnormal psychology.

name: Statistics for Psychology
description: This course covers the basic concepts of statistical methods as they apply to behavioral research and data analysis in psychology. Topics include descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, probability theory, sampling distributions, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and analysis of variance.

name: Research Methods in Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the principles and techniques involved in conducting psychological research. Topics include research design, sampling procedures, measurement techniques, data collection methods, data analysis, and interpretation of results.

name: Social Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the study of social behavior and mental processes in individuals and groups. Topics include social influence, attitudes, persuasion, group dynamics, intergroup relations, aggression, and prosocial behavior.

name: Cognitive Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the study of mental processes such as attention, perception, memory, language, and problem solving. Topics include information processing, cognitive development, and cognitive neuroscience.

name: Developmental Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the study of human development across the lifespan. Topics include physical, cognitive, and social-emotional development, as well as major theories of development.

name: Abnormal Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the major diagnostic categories and psychological disorders of clinical psychology. Topics include the etiology, symptoms, and treatment of disorders such as anxiety, mood, psychotic, and personality disorders.

name: Personality Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the study of personality and individual differences. Topics include major theoretical perspectives, measurement techniques, assessment of personality traits, and the relationship between personality and behavior.

name: Sensation and Perception
description: This course introduces students to the neural and cognitive processes involved in sensation and perception. Topics include sensation, perception, attention, and the relationship between sensory experience and behavior.

name: Cultural Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the study of cultural influences on human behavior and mental processes. Topics include cultural norms, values, beliefs, and practices, as well as cross-cultural comparisons of cognition, emotion, and perception.

name: Introduction to Psychology
description: This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts of psychology and explores ways of understanding behavior and experience, including perception, learning, memory, motivation, emotion, personality, social behavior, and psychological disorders.

name: Research Methods in Psychology
description: This course covers research design and analysis methods for psychology. Students will learn how to design empirical studies, collect and analyze data, and report results.

name: Statistics for Psychology
description: This course covers descriptive and inferential statistics for psychology. Students will learn how to use statistical software to analyze data and interpret results.

name: Abnormal Psychology
description: This course examines the definition, causes, and treatments of abnormal behavior, including various forms of psychopathology, such as anxiety disorders, mood disorders, personality disorders, and psychotic disorders.

name: Social Psychology
description: This course explores how social factors shape behavior, thoughts, and emotions. Topics include social influence, group dynamics, intergroup relations, prejudice and discrimination, and prosocial behavior.

name: Developmental Psychology
description: This course covers human development across the lifespan, including physical, cognitive, and social-emotional development. Topics include nature vs. nurture, attachment, language development, and aging.

name: Cognitive Psychology
description: This course covers topics related to mental processes, such as attention, perception, memory, language, and problem-solving. Students will explore cognitive psychology research methods and theories.

name: Personality Psychology
description: This course covers theories and research related to personality, including psychodynamic, trait, social-cognitive, and humanistic approaches. Students will explore the influence of personality on behavior and well-being.

name: History and Systems of Psychology
description: This course explores the historical and philosophical foundations of psychology, and how different schools of thought have contributed to the development of the discipline.

name: Psychology of Learning
description: This course covers various theories and approaches to learning, including classical and operant conditioning, observational learning, and cognitive approaches. Students will learn how to apply learning principles to real-world situations.

name: Sensation and Perception
description: This course covers the basic principles and research methods of sensation and perception, including how we perceive color, sound, touch, and other sensory information.

name: Clinical Psychology
description: This course covers various approaches to clinical psychology, including psychoanalytic, cognitive-behavioral, and humanistic approaches. Students will explore the diagnosis, assessment, and treatment of psychological disorders.

name: Health Psychology
description: This course covers how biological, psychological, and social factors influence health and illness. Students will explore how to promote health and prevent illness through behavior change and other interventions.

name: Positive Psychology
description: This course examines human flourishing and well-being, and explores positive emotions, positive relationships, and positive institutions. Students will learn about the research and applications of positive psychology.
